questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his ETCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Venous Air Embolism:
  • • Venous Air Embolism:
  • • Definition: It refers to the entry of air into the venous system, which can then travel to the heart and block the pulmonary circulation. Presentation: A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. A "mill wheel" murmur might be heard on auscultation. Relevance to the Scenario: The sudden drop in ETCO2, combined with hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia following manipulation of the internal jugular vein during surgery in a head-up position, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.
  • • Acute myocardial infarction:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.
  • • Option A. Bronchial asthma:
  • • Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.
  • • Option B. Renal failure:
  • • Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.
  • • Option C. Emphysema:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 3 min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen. This is typically done by giving 100% oxygen to the patient for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by asking them to take 8 vital capacity breaths. This process helps to lengthen the apnea time, providing an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.
  • • There are two main methods commonly used for preoxygenation:
  • • The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs. The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. Research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.
  • • The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs.
  • • The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. Research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 1 min: This duration is insufficient for effective preoxygenation, as it does not allow adequate time to replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.
  • • Option A. 1 min:
  • • Option C. 5-7 min: While longer preoxygenation can ensure thorough denitrogenation, it is not typically necessary beyond the 3 minutes required for effective preoxygenation.
  • • Option C. 5-7 min:
  • • Option D. 5 min : Preoxygenation for this duration can be effective, but the standard practice is to use 3 minutes as it is usually sufficient to achieve the desired effect.
  • • Option D. 5 min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Preoxygenation for tracheal intubation is effectively achieved by administering 100% oxygen for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by taking 8 vital capacity breaths.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 1380
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 1380

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to assess the depth of anesthesia in patients with significant muscle activity or electrical interference? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Entropy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Entropy monitoring is particularly useful for assessing the depth of anesthesia in scenarios with significant muscle activity or electrical interference:
  • • Principle: Entropy monitoring analyzes EEG and electromyographic (EMG) activity. It provides two values— State Entropy (SE) , derived mainly from EEG, and Response Entropy (RE) , which includes EMG activity. Advantages over BIS: In cases where muscle activity or electrical interference might affect BIS readings, entropy monitoring can provide more reliable data by separately analyzing EMG activity.
  • • Principle: Entropy monitoring analyzes EEG and electromyographic (EMG) activity. It provides two values— State Entropy (SE) , derived mainly from EEG, and Response Entropy (RE) , which includes EMG activity.
  • • Principle:
  • • State Entropy (SE)
  • • Response Entropy (RE)
  • • Advantages over BIS: In cases where muscle activity or electrical interference might affect BIS readings, entropy monitoring can provide more reliable data by separately analyzing EMG activity.
  • • Advantages over BIS:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. EEG: While the EEG is the foundation for both BIS and entropy monitoring, it is not typically used directly in clinical practice due to its complexity and the need for advanced interpretation.
  • • Option A. EEG:
  • • Option B. Neuromuscular Transmission (NMT) Monitoring: NMT monitoring is used to assess neuromuscular blockade and is not intended for assessing the depth of anesthesia.
  • • Option B. Neuromuscular Transmission (NMT) Monitoring:
  • • Option D. Bispectral Index: BIS is the most commonly used monitor for anesthesia depth under typical conditions. However, in scenarios with excessive muscle activity or electrical interference, BIS readings may be less reliable compared to entropy monitoring.
  • • Option D. Bispectral Index:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Entropy monitoring, which evaluates both EEG and EMG activity, is particularly effective for assessing the depth of anesthesia in patients with significant muscle activity or electrical interference, offering an alternative to BIS in challenging scenarios.

questions.text: What alternative drug can be considered for cardiac arrest in cases of refractory asystole? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vasopressin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vasopressin is an alternative drug that can be considered for cardiac arrest, especially in cases of refractory asystole:
  • • Mechanism of Action: Vasopressin is a potent vasoconstrictor that acts on V1 receptors in vascular smooth muscle. This vasoconstriction helps shunt blood to vital organs during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). Use in Cardiac Arrest: Although no longer routinely recommended in updated guidelines, vasopressin is still a viable alternative in some refractory cases when epinephrine is ineffective or unavailable. Dose: 40 IU IV as a one-time dose during resuscitation.
  • • Mechanism of Action: Vasopressin is a potent vasoconstrictor that acts on V1 receptors in vascular smooth muscle. This vasoconstriction helps shunt blood to vital organs during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • Use in Cardiac Arrest: Although no longer routinely recommended in updated guidelines, vasopressin is still a viable alternative in some refractory cases when epinephrine is ineffective or unavailable.
  • • Use in Cardiac Arrest:
  • • Dose: 40 IU IV as a one-time dose during resuscitation.
  • • Dose:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is primarily used in cases of ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) when defibrillation fails. It is not the drug of choice for asystole.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone:
  • • Option C. Sodium Bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is occasionally used in specific scenarios such as severe acidosis or hyperkalemia but is not a primary treatment for asystole or cardiac arrest.
  • • Option C. Sodium Bicarbonate:
  • • Option D. Atropine: Atropine is no longer routinely recommended for asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA) in cardiac arrest due to lack of evidence supporting its effectiveness.
  • • Option D. Atropine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasopressin can be considered an alternative to epinephrine in specific cases of refractory asystole during cardiac arrest, though its use is not routine under current guidelines. Understanding drug-specific roles is critical in the management of different cardiac arrest rhythms.

questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. C fibres

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. Local anaesthetics work by blocking sodium channels, which prevents the initiation and propagation of action potentials in nerves. The effectiveness of local anaesthetics depends on the diameter and myelination of the nerve fibres.
  • • Type C fibres are unmyelinated and have the smallest diameter, making them the least susceptible to local anaesthetics. This means they require a higher concentration of the anaesthetic to achieve the same level of blockade as larger, myelinated fibres.
  • • The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is:
  • • B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C
  • • B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C
  • • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres
  • • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres
  • • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres
  • • B fibres
  • • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres
  • • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres
  • • C fibres
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. A-delta: These are myelinated fibres with a small diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to C fibres but less susceptible than larger, myelinated fibres like A-beta and A-alpha.
  • • Option A. A-delta:
  • • Option B. A-gamma: These are myelinated fibres with a moderate diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta fibres but less susceptible than A-beta and A-alpha fibres.
  • • Option B. A-gamma:
  • • Option C. A-beta: These are myelinated fibres with a larger diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta and A-gamma fibres.
  • • Option C. A-beta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Type C nerve fibres are the least susceptible to local anaesthetics due to their small diameter and lack of myelination.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs 1416-1417
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs
  • ➤ 1416-1417

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.
  • • Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz : This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz
  • • Option B. 2 Hz : This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option B. 2 Hz
  • • Option C. 20 Hz : This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.
  • • Option C. 20 Hz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.
  • • Option A. PPV with ETT:
  • • Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.
  • • Option C. Oxygen therapy:
  • • Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.
  • • Option D. Intubation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency. (INICET MAY 2022)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Potency of Anesthetic Agents:
  • • Potency of Anesthetic Agents:
  • • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.
  • • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.
  • • MAC Values:
  • • MAC Values:
  • • Methoxyflurane: 0.16 Halothane: 0.75 Isoflurane: 1.4 Nitrous oxide: 104
  • • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • • Halothane: 0.75
  • • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • • Nitrous oxide: 104
  • • Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):
  • • Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):
  • • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent. Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide. Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide. Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.
  • • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • • Methoxyflurane:
  • • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • • Halothane:
  • • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • • Isoflurane:
  • • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.
  • • Nitrous oxide:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.
  • • Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane:
  • • Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.
  • • Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide:
  • • Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.
  • • Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder

options.label: B
options.text: Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

options.label: C
options.text: If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen

options.label: D
options.text: Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.correct_answer: B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: Traditionally, to prevent blood from clotting inside the syringe when obtaining an ABG, a small amount of heparin was added to the syringe. However, in contemporary practice, syringes used for ABG are pre-heparinized, which means they already contain a coating of dry heparin that will mix with the blood sample and prevent clotting. Adding additional heparin to such a syringe is unnecessary and can dilute the sample, potentially altering the results.
  • • Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder: This statement is accurate. A patient can have a mixed acid-base disorder where two primary disorders (e.g., metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis) coexist and "cancel" each other out, leading to a seemingly "normal" pH. However, when the components of the arterial blood gas (ABG) like PaCO2 and HCO3- are evaluated, abnormalities can be detected.
  • • Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder:
  • • Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen: The modified Allen's test is a simple way to evaluate the collateral blood flow to the hand via the ulnar artery. Before taking a sample or placing an arterial line in the radial artery, it's a recommended step to ensure that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand will still receive adequate blood flow. If the test is negative (indicative of inadequate collateral flow), it's safer to choose an alternate site for arterial puncture.
  • • Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen:
  • • Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: The radial artery is commonly chosen for ABG sampling and arterial line placement due to its accessibility, the presence of collateral blood flow (via the ulnar artery), and its relatively superficial location which makes puncture technically easier. Furthermore, complications like hematoma or injury are less problematic at this location when compared to other potential sites, such as the femoral artery.
  • • Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Adding extra heparin to pre-heparinized ABG syringes is unnecessary and can alter the blood sample.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2 to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax : A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax
  • • Option C. Endobronchial Intubation : Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.
  • • Option C. Endobronchial Intubation
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm : Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.

options.label: B
options.text: Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.correct_answer: B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.
  • • Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.
  • • Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse:
  • • Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.
  • • Option C. Observe:
  • • Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.
  • • Option D. Ignore and continue to walk:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs
  • ➤ 2715-2716

questions.text: A patient was undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. For intubation, 90 mg of rocuronium was given, but the anesthesiologist was unable to intubate the patient. What is the drug given for immediate reversal of the neuromuscular blockade? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block. In a matter of few seconds the patient suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the correct 1 st line treatment of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intra lipid infusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's symptoms of hypotension and arrhythmias after the administration of 0.5% bupivacaine suggest local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation in significant amounts. Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy is considered the first-line treatment for LAST. It works by creating a "lipid sink" that helps to sequester the lipophilic local anesthetic away from target organs, particularly the heart and brain.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Invasive Ventilation: This is provided if the patient is not able to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation on their own. It is supportive care and does not directly counteract the toxicity of the local anesthetic.
  • • Option A. Invasive Ventilation:
  • • Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate): This can be used to treat metabolic acidosis, which may occur secondary to hypoxia or cardiac arrest. While it can help in the supportive management of LAST, it is not the first line for the toxicity itself.
  • • Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate):
  • • Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR): This is initiated in the case of cardiac arrest. While it's a crucial component of resuscitation, it's not a first-line treatment for the toxicity unless the patient has progressed to cardiac arrest.
  • • Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy, which helps to reduce the systemic toxicity of lipophilic local anesthetic agents such as bupivacaine.

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.
  • • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.
  • • Decreases need of intubation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.
  • • Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space:
  • • Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.
  • • Option C. Heating and humidification:
  • • Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.
  • • Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.
  • ➤ While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

questions.text: What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? ( INICET May 2023) 1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute 2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute 3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm 4. Allow chest recoil
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate:
  • • 3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).
  • • 3. Depth of Compression:
  • • 4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.
  • • 4. Chest Recoil:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only:
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4:
  • • Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.
  • • Option D. 1 only:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hofmann’s degradation? FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cisatracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is a temperature and pH-dependent process that does not require enzymatic activity for metabolism. This makes it particularly useful for patients with certain types of organ dysfunction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Mivacurium: It is a short-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily broken down by plasma cholinesterase and does not significantly undergo Hofmann elimination.
  • • Option B. Mivacurium:
  • • Option C. Pancuronium: This is a long-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and it does not undergo Hofmann elimination.
  • • Option C. Pancuronium:
  • • Option D. Vecuronium: Like pancuronium, it is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys and does not undergo Hofmann degradation.
  • • Option D. Vecuronium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisatracurium is unique among the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents for undergoing Hofmann elimination, a process that allows safe use in patients with hepatic and renal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16: Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume:
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn? (INICET NOV 2022) 22G cannula 24G IV cannula 5-mL syringe Adhesive tape Normal saline
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.
  • • 2. 24G IV cannula:
  • • 3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.
  • • 3. 5-mL syringe:
  • • 4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.
  • • 4. Adhesive tape:
  • • 5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.
  • • 5. Normal saline:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • 1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.
  • • 1. 22G IV cannula:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an intravenous induction agent? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Propofol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and produces a smooth and quick recovery, but can cause hypotension and respiratory depression.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic. It is not used as an intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia. Instead, it's used for regional anesthesia like epidural or nerve blocks. When administered systemically, it can be toxic, especially to the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  • • Option B. Bupivacaine:
  • • Option C. Dexmedetomidine: Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It provides sedation without causing respiratory depression. Although it is used for sedation in the ICU and for certain procedures, it's not typically used as a primary induction agent for general anesthesia.
  • • Option C. Dexmedetomidine:
  • • Option D. Neostigmine : Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It is used to reverse neuromuscular blockade (from non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers) at the end of a surgery. It is not used as an induction agent for anesthesia.
  • • Option D. Neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Propofol is a widely used intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia due to its rapid onset and smooth recovery profile.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in adults? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L1-L2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Termination of the Spinal Cord:
  • • Termination of the Spinal Cord:
  • • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris. Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance. Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.
  • • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris.
  • • Anatomy:
  • • Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance.
  • • Details:
  • • Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.
  • • Adult Spinal Cord End:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. L3-L4: This is incorrect as the spinal cord in adults does not extend to this level. This level is generally where lumbar punctures are performed to avoid the spinal cord.
  • • Option A. L3-L4:
  • • Option C. T12-L1: This is slightly higher than the actual end of the spinal cord in adults. The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2, not T12-L1.
  • • Option C. T12-L1:
  • • Option D. L2-L3: This is incorrect as well because the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults, not extending to L2-L3.
  • • Option D. L2-L3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal cord in adults terminates at the lower border of L1, at the region called the conus medullaris, with the cauda equina continuing downward from this point.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents is most likely to cause adrenal suppression as a side effect? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Etomidate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Etomidate is most associated with adrenal suppression:
  • • Mechanism of Action: Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme critical in the synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. Clinical Relevance: Even a single dose of etomidate can cause temporary adrenal suppression, which may be significant in critically ill patients. It is a concern when etomidate is used for induction in sepsis or other conditions where adrenal function is crucial for hemodynamic stability. While etomidate is preferred for its minimal cardiovascular effects, the risk of adrenal suppression limits its prolonged use.
  • • Mechanism of Action: Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme critical in the synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • • Mechanism of Action:
  • • Clinical Relevance: Even a single dose of etomidate can cause temporary adrenal suppression, which may be significant in critically ill patients. It is a concern when etomidate is used for induction in sepsis or other conditions where adrenal function is crucial for hemodynamic stability.
  • • Clinical Relevance:
  • • While etomidate is preferred for its minimal cardiovascular effects, the risk of adrenal suppression limits its prolonged use.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine does not cause adrenal suppression. Its primary effects include dissociation and analgesia. It is hemodynamically stable and may even stimulate endogenous catecholamine release.
  • • Option A. Ketamine:
  • • Option B. Propofol: Propofol is not associated with adrenal suppression. Its side effects include hypotension, bradycardia, and pain on injection.
  • • Option B. Propofol:
  • • Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone does not inhibit adrenal function. Its adverse effects include respiratory depression, hypotension, and potential tissue necrosis with extravasation.
  • • Option D. Thiopentone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate is the anesthetic agent most likely to cause adrenal suppression due to its inhibition of 11β-hydroxylase. This makes it less favorable in conditions requiring intact adrenal function, despite its favorable hemodynamic profile.

questions.text: In which of the following devices is a beveled tip a key feature for its function? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Nasopharyngeal airway

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A beveled tip is a key feature of the nasopharyngeal airway:
  • • The beveled tip of the nasopharyngeal airway is designed to facilitate easy insertion into the nasal passage, minimizing trauma to the nasal mucosa. This design feature ensures the airway is less likely to cause discomfort or bleeding, making it a preferred choice in situations where oral airway placement is not possible. The beveled shape allows smooth passage even in patients with partial nasal obstruction.
  • • The beveled tip of the nasopharyngeal airway is designed to facilitate easy insertion into the nasal passage, minimizing trauma to the nasal mucosa.
  • • This design feature ensures the airway is less likely to cause discomfort or bleeding, making it a preferred choice in situations where oral airway placement is not possible.
  • • The beveled shape allows smooth passage even in patients with partial nasal obstruction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endotracheal tube: The endotracheal tube is characterized by the presence of Murphy's eye, which provides an alternate path for ventilation if the main lumen is blocked. The beveled tip is not a primary distinguishing feature here.
  • • Option B. Endotracheal tube:
  • • Option C. Laryngoscope: A laryngoscope is a tool used for visualizing the larynx during intubation. It has no beveled components as part of its design.
  • • Option C. Laryngoscope:
  • • Option D. Bronchoscope: A bronchoscope is used for airway visualization and is not characterized by the presence of a beveled tip.
  • • Option D. Bronchoscope:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasopharyngeal airway is uniquely designed with a beveled tip to allow atraumatic and smooth insertion through the nasal passage, ensuring a patent airway in scenarios where oral devices are contraindicated. Understanding device-specific features like the beveled tip (nasopharyngeal airway) or Murphy's eye (endotracheal tube) is crucial for clinical practice.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Capnography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism. It does not measure cardiac output. Capnography is commonly used to monitor end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.
  • • Option A. Thermal dilution technique:
  • • Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.
  • • Option C. Esophageal Doppler:
  • • Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.
  • • Option D. Echocardiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air and is not used to determine cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Well controlled asthma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Well controlled asthma: Asthma, when well controlled, should not significantly increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Uncontrolled or poorly controlled asthma, on the other hand, would be a risk factor due to increased airway hyperreactivity and potential for bronchospasm or other complications in the postoperative period.
  • • Well controlled asthma:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. BMI > 30: Obesity can reduce functional residual capacity and total lung volume, which increases the risk of atelectasis after surgery. Additionally, obese patients often have decreased diaphragmatic movement and may have associated conditions like obstructive sleep apnea, which can contribute to postoperative respiratory issues.
  • • Option A. BMI > 30:
  • • Option C. Upper abdominal surgery: Upper abdominal surgeries are associated with a higher risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. The diaphragmatic movement can be impaired after these surgeries, leading to decreased lung expansion and atelectasis, especially in the bases of the lungs. This can increase the chances of postoperative pneumonia and other respiratory issues.
  • • Option C. Upper abdominal surgery:
  • • Option D. Age > 70 years: Advanced age is a recognized risk factor for postoperative complications, including pulmonary complications. Older patients often have reduced physiological reserve, which means they have less ability to compensate for postoperative stress and changes in lung function. Furthermore, they are more likely to have comorbid conditions that can contribute to respiratory issues.
  • • Option D. Age > 70 years:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Well-controlled asthma is not a significant risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications, unlike other conditions such as obesity, upper abdominal surgery, and advanced age.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for severe pre-eclampsia with impending eclampsia is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) anesthesia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) anesthesia is particularly beneficial in severe pre-eclampsia with impending eclampsia:
  • • Spinal component: Provides rapid onset of anesthesia for urgent procedures, such as cesarean delivery, which may be required in cases of severe pre-eclampsia. Epidural component: Allows for titration of anesthesia/analgesia over time, providing flexibility in management and maintaining hemodynamic stability. In pre-eclampsia, avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations is critical. The epidural component in CSE allows for controlled administration of local anesthetic, minimizing the risk of sudden drops in blood pressure.
  • • Spinal component: Provides rapid onset of anesthesia for urgent procedures, such as cesarean delivery, which may be required in cases of severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Spinal component:
  • • Epidural component: Allows for titration of anesthesia/analgesia over time, providing flexibility in management and maintaining hemodynamic stability.
  • • Epidural component:
  • • In pre-eclampsia, avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations is critical. The epidural component in CSE allows for controlled administration of local anesthetic, minimizing the risk of sudden drops in blood pressure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Spinal anesthesia: While spinal anesthesia provides rapid onset, its fixed dose can result in significant hemodynamic instability due to a sudden drop in systemic vascular resistance, making it less suitable for severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Option A. Spinal anesthesia:
  • • Option B. General anesthesia: General anesthesia is generally avoided in pre-eclampsia unless absolutely necessary (e.g., contraindications to neuraxial anesthesia or severe coagulopathy). Challenges include airway difficulties, increased risk of aspiration, and potential neonatal depression due to placental drug transfer.
  • • Option B. General anesthesia:
  • • Option D. Caudal block: A caudal block is rarely used in obstetric anesthesia and is not appropriate for cesarean delivery or managing pre-eclampsia.
  • • Option D. Caudal block:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) anesthesia is particularly advantageous in severe pre-eclampsia with impending eclampsia due to its rapid onset (spinal) and controllable hemodynamic effects (epidural). This method provides a balanced approach, ensuring maternal and fetal safety in high-risk obstetric situations.
